conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, and their size and shape depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object.
Initially, the light source is at a certain height, casting elongated shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground because the light source is relatively low.
When the light source moves upward, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes, becoming more perpendicular to the ground.
As the light source moves upward, the shadows will become shorter because the light rays hit the objects at a steeper angle, reducing the length of the shadows.
The position of the shadows will change, moving closer to the base of the objects because the light rays come from a higher angle, causing the shadows to fall more directly beneath the objects.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will become shorter and move closer to the base of the objects.
